parts.content: How can data drift affect the performance of machine learning models?

parts.args: {"query":"data drift affect performance of machine learning models"}

content.title: Data Drift
content.description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
content.section:
## Use Cases

You can evaluate data drift in various scenarios:

* **Monitoring ML Model Performance**: When true labels or actuals are unavailable, monitoring feature drift and prediction drift helps check if the model operates in a familiar environment.
* **Debugging ML Model Quality Decay**: Evaluate data drift to explore changes in feature patterns if a drop in model quality is observed.
* **Understanding Model Drift in Offline Environment**: Explore historical data drift to understand past changes and define optimal detection and retraining strategies.
* **Deciding on Model Retraining**: Verify if retraining is necessary. If no data drift is detected, the environment is stable.

<Info>
  For a conceptual explanation, read about [Data Drift](https://www.evidentlyai.com/ml-in-production/data-drift) and [Concept Drift](https://www.evidentlyai.com/ml-in-production/concept-drift).
</Info>

content.title: Data Drift
content.description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
content.section:
## Overview

The `DataDriftPreset` evaluates shifts in data distribution between two datasets to detect significant changes.

* **Column Drift**: Checks for shifts in each column. The drift detection method is chosen automatically based on the column type and number of observations.
* **Target / Prediction Drift**: If your dataset includes Prediction or Target values, these will be evaluated along with other columns.
* **Overall Dataset Drift**: Returns the share of drifting columns in the dataset. By default, dataset drift is detected if at least 50% of columns drift.

The additional Test Suite view is available if tests are enabled.

<Info>
  **Data Drift Explainer**: Read about [Data Drift Methods](/metrics/explainer_drift) and default algorithm.
</Info>

content.title: Data Drift
content.description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
content.section:
## Report Customization

Multiple customization options are available:

**Select Columns**: Apply Drift Detection only to specific columns using the `columns` parameter.

**Change Drift Parameters**: Modify drift detection methods, set different thresholds, or implement a custom method.

<Info>
  **Drift Detection Parameters**: Learn available methods and parameters in [Drift Customization](/metrics/customize_data_drift).
</Info>

**Modify Report Composition**: Add other metrics to the report for more comprehensive evaluation. Options include evaluating drift in the Prediction column or adding data quality checks.

<Info>
  **Custom Report**: Check how to create a [Report](/docs/library/report) and add [Tests](/docs/library/tests).
</Info>

content.title: Data Drift
content.description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
content.section:
## Data Requirements

* **Input Columns**: You can provide any non-empty input columns.
* **Two Datasets**: Must always pass both the current and reference datasets.
* **Set Column Types (Optional)**: The Preset evaluates drift for numerical, categorical, or text data, and column types can be specified explicitly for better accuracy.

<Info>
  **Data Schema Mapping**: Use the [data definition](/docs/library/data_definition) to map your input data.
</Info>

content.title: Data Drift
content.description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.
content.section:
## Report Usage

To run a Preset on your data, comparing `current` data to `ref` data:

```python
report = Report([
    DataDriftPreset(),
])

my_eval = report.run(current, ref)
```

content.description: Overview of the Data Drift Preset.

## Use Cases

You can evaluate data drift in various scenarios:

* **Monitoring ML Model Performance**: When true labels or actuals are unavailable, monitoring feature drift and prediction drift helps check if the model operates in a familiar environment.
* **Debugging ML Model Quality Decay**: Evaluate data drift to explore changes in feature patterns if a drop in model quality is observed.
* **Understanding Model Drift in Offline Environment**: Explore historical data drift to understand past changes and define optimal detection and retraining strategies.

<Info>

content.title: Evaluations
content.description: Available metrics, tests and how to customize them.
content.section:
### Data Drift

Here, you will learn how to customize data drift detection. This is essential for maintaining the relevance and accuracy of models as their underlying data may change over time.

content.title: Data drift
content.section:
## Text Data Drift

Evidently detects text content drift using a **domain classifier**, training a binary model to distinguish between reference and current distributions.

If the model confidently identifies which text samples belong to the "newer" data, this indicates significant differences between datasets.

<Info>
More information about the domain classifier approach can be found in the [paper ](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.11953.pdf)“Failing Loudly: An Empirical Study of Methods for Detecting Dataset Shift.”
</Info>

The drift score in this case is the ROC AUC of the resulting classifier. The default threshold for larger data (> 1000 observations) is ROC AUC > 0.55. For smaller data (<= 1000 observations), the threshold is set at the 95th percentile of the performance of a random classifier.

<Info>
**How this works.** The ROC-AUC score of the classifier on a validation dataset is compared against a distribution generated from 1000 random classifier calculations.
</Info>

If drift is detected, Evidently calculates the **top features** of the domain classifier, revealing specific words indicating whether a sample belongs to the reference or current datasets.

<Tip>
**Text descriptors drift** can also be analyzed. You can check for distribution drift in text descriptors like text length by employing numerical/categorical drift detection methods.
</Tip>

content.title: Overview
content.section:
## Data Drift Detection

### Description
Data distribution drift detection.

### Link
[View Data Drift](https://example.com/metrics/preset_data_drift)

content.title: Data drift
content.section:
## Data Requirements

To evaluate data drift, the following requirements must be met:

**Two datasets**: You need to pass two datasets: current (evaluated for drift) and reference (benchmark).

**Non-empty columns**: Ensure that the columns tested for drift are not empty. If any columns are empty in either dataset, Evidently will not calculate distribution drift and will raise an error.

**Empty values**: Columns with empty or infinite values will be filtered out when calculating drift.

<Note>
By default, drift tests do **not** respond to changes in the number of empty values, so it is recommended to run separate tests on the share of nulls in the dataset or columns.
</Note>

parts.content:
Data drift occurs when the statistical properties of the input data used by a machine learning model change over time, which can significantly impact the model's performance. Here’s how data drift can affect machine learning models:

1. **Model Performance Degradation**: When the input features that the model was trained on change, the model might no longer make accurate predictions. This can lead to a drop in the accuracy of the model since it is no longer operating in a familiar environment.

2. **Feature and Prediction Drift**: Data drift can manifest as shifts in features (feature drift) or in the model's predictions (prediction drift). Monitoring these shifts is essential; otherwise, performance could deteriorate unnoticed [Data Drift](https://github.com/evidentlyai/docs/tree/main/docs-main/metrics/preset_data_drift.mdx).

3. **Debugging Model Quality**: If a model's performance drops, analyzing data drift helps identify which features have changed and how they may be impacting model predictions. This analysis is critical for debugging and understanding the underlying causes of model performance decay [Data Drift](https://github.com/evidentlyai/docs/tree/main/docs-main/metrics/preset_data_drift.mdx).

4. **Need for Retraining**: Detecting data drift may indicate that the model needs to be retrained. If substantial drift is observed, it suggests that the model's assumptions no longer hold, indicating that retraining could help adapt the model to the new data distribution [Data Drift](https://github.com/evidentlyai/docs/tree/main/docs-main/metrics/preset_data_drift.mdx).

5. **Monitoring Systems**: Establishing a robust monitoring system to regularly assess data drift is essential. This can involve setting thresholds for acceptable drift levels and determining when retraining should occur based on these metrics [Data Drift](https://github.com/evidentlyai/docs/tree/main/docs-main/metrics/preset_data_drift.mdx).

By actively monitoring and addressing data drift, you can help maintain the relevance and accuracy of your machine learning models over time.
